data.title: 99 Shades of Pink Color With Names, HEX, RGB, & CMYK
data.meta_description: Looking for beautiful shades of pink? We compiled a comprehensive list of pink shades with names, HEX, RGB, and CMYK codes.
data.text: Looking for beautiful shades of pink? You’re in the right place! We compiled a comprehensive list of pink shades with names, HEX, RGB, and CMYK codes. Copy the following code to use this infographic on your site. Otherwise, no rights of use will be granted. Thanks! Source: Colors Explained, shades of pink Shades of Pink Color Pink is one of the most common colors in the modern world. You can find pink things in nature or in the toy section for girls. You can also find it in the branding colors of companies with young audiences or those who want to stand out from their competitor by making a statement. Either way, your design or website is bound to turn heads if you’re planning to use a pink shade or two in it. That’s why we will talk about 99 shades of pink color in today’s article, including their names, hex, RGB, and CMYK codes. With these codes, designers, students, artists, and anyone who would like to use these pink shades in their designs can easily pick the right color without hassle. Enjoy! Pink facts: Pink is one of the least popular favorite colors in western societies. RGB 246, 74, 138 CMYK 0, 70, 44, 4 Irresistible HEX #B3446C RGB 179, 68, 108 CMYK 0, 62, 40, 30 History of Pink Pink has not always been a baby girl’s color. The way people perceive pink changed drastically over the years. Back in the 18th century, pink was used by both men and women of western European aristocrats. Beyond that, when pink and blue were associated as gender signifiers, pink was often associated with boys for its resemblance with red, an aggressive hue. The recent associations of this color as we know it today started around the mid-1800s when men in western societies wore dark hues more often, leaving brighter and pastel tones to women. By the turn of the century, pink had entered the mainstream — and its status shifted in the process. The advent of industrialization and mass production led to the growing cheap dyes like magenta, which resulted in bright, garish versions of the color. Pink went from luxury to working class and, as a color often worn by prostitutes at the time, from sophisticated to vulgar. On top of that, pink was the color used by the German Army during WWII to identify gays, which is one of the reasons fashionistas believe it became a “girl’s color.” Today, the meaning of pink continues to shift and is often a symbol of resistance, hope, and positivity. For instance, think of the Breast Cancer campaign or the Pride Flags. There is no doubt pink is a powerful color. Color Palette Pink Here are some gorgeous pink palettes for inspiration. Pink Fields Pink Sky Morning, Beauty Pink for Boys Hot Pink Most Popular Shades of Pink Color It isn’t difficult to find pink shades in nature or shops, especially in this modern society. Still, these are the most popular shades of pink. Baby Pink Baby pink is a calm pink that is actually considered a very light shade of red. The first recorded use of baby pink as a color name in English was in 1928. Barbie Pink Barbie pink is a dark, energetic shade of pink. This color became famous because of the Barbie doll by Mattel. Pantone 219C is the color used by Mattel’s Barbie in logos, packaging, and promotional materials. Fuchsia Fuchsia is located in the meeting point between pink and purple on the color wheel. However, fuchsia is considered a bright shade of pink in everyday use. Fuchsia and magenta are just different names for the same color in the RGB model. Hot Pink Hot pink has appeared in the vanguard of multiple revolutions and resistances. Besides, hot pink was called shocking pink in the 1930s, hot pink in the 1950s, and kinky pink in the 1960s. Watermelon Watermelon pink is a bright, saturated shade of pink, which is the color of the perfectly ripe interior of the watermelon fruit. What Are the Different Shades of Pink Color? Some of the most prevalent pink shades are bubblegum, baby pink, cerise, hot pink, flamingo, bright pink, pale pink, and cherry pink. What Is the Prettiest Shade of Pink? Obviously, color preference is personal, but baby pink, watermelon, cherry blossom, Barbie, and French pink are some of the most common pink shades. What Is the Darkest Color Pink? Dark Pink (#B03060) is the darkest shade of pink and it might be confused with red when next to a light background. What Is the Lightest Color Pink? Soft Pink (#FDDDE6) is a soothing and very light shade of pink. What Is the Hex Code of Pink Color? The hex code of the purest pink is #FF00FF. What Is the RGB Code of Pink Color? The RGB code for the purest pink is 255, 0, 255. What Is the CMYK Code of Pink Color? The CMYK code for the purest pink is 0, 100, 0, 00. Final Thoughts on Shades of Pink That’s a wrap! We hope these pink color names and incredible shades of pink will be useful for your design or website. Be sure to browse our site to learn more about pink and all other colors of the rainbow.
